results.headline: Review: In ‘Level Up,’ Yanked From a Video Game Stupor to a Real Mission
results.summary_short: This British indie offers a cynical vision of technology-fostered callousness, a running-man cocktail of brutality spiked with low-level humor.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Level Up

results.headline: Review: Love, Loss and Spiritual Torment in ‘The Sea of Trees’
results.summary_short: Matthew McConaughey stars as a professor who enters a Japanese forest to end his life. There he meets a businessman, played by Ken Watanabe, with the same goal.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sea of Trees

results.headline: Review: In an Obama Biopic, the Audacity of Hagiography?
results.summary_short: The writer-director Richard Tanne builds on the Obamas’ first date, in Chicago, in this worshipful film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Southside With You

results.headline: Review: ‘Kate Plays Christine,’ a Blurring of Fact and Fiction in a Suicide Story
results.summary_short: This movie is a sequel of sorts to Robert Greene’s “Actress,” which focuses on boundaries between actors playing themselves and fictional characters.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kate Plays Christine

results.headline: Review: In ‘Happy Hour,’ the Effects of One Divorce on Four Women
results.summary_short: Ryusuke Hamaguchi’s leisurely paced film observes the minute, everyday interactions that cause people to fall in — or, here, mostly out of — love.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Happy Hour

results.headline: Review: Wrestling With Gay Identity and Parental Wishes in ‘Spa Night’
results.summary_short: Chronicling the tensions facing a Korean-American teenager, Andrew Ahn’s first feature contemplates the anxieties of outsiders trying to find their place in America.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Spa Night

results.headline: Review: Daniel Radcliffe Battles Homegrown Extremists in ‘Imperium’
results.summary_short: Inspired by the career of a former F.B.I. agent who infiltrated white supremacist groups, the film may get moviegoers’ blood boiling.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Imperium

results.headline: Review: ‘Ixcanul,’ From Luminous Ritual to Emotional Explosions
results.summary_short: The first feature from Jayro Bustamante contrasts a quiet agrarian life in Guatemala with a hard-hitting tragedy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ixcanul

results.headline: Review: In ‘Kubo and the Two Strings,’ Origami Fuels an Animated Quest
results.summary_short: This movie from Laika Films (“Coraline” and “ParaNorman”) combines stop-motion animation and computer-generated backgrounds with a moving and magical tale.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kubo and the Two Strings

results.headline: Review: ‘War Dogs,’ an Absurd (and True) Gunrunning Tale
results.summary_short: Jonah Hill and Miles Teller play 20-something entrepreneurs who plunge into the weaponry business and end up in over their heads.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of War Dogs

results.headline: Review: ‘Morris From America’: A 13-Year-Old Stranger in a Strange Land
results.summary_short: An American teenager seeks his place in the world in Heidelberg, Germany.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Morris From America

results.headline: Review: ‘Ben-Hur’ Is a Savage Update for a New Generation
results.summary_short: Timur Bekmambetov’s adaptation of the sword-and-sandals spectacle offers a rip-roaring chariot race but is largely devoid of pious posturing.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ben-Hur

results.display_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World
results.headline: Review: ‘Lo and Behold,’ the Danger, and Potential, of the Digital Revolution
results.summary_short: Werner Herzog interviews experts and others about the internet, robots, artificial intelligence and other aspects of our technology-driven world.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World

results.headline: Review: Treasonous Play for Justice in ‘The People vs. Fritz Bauer’
results.summary_short: The film follows the West German prosecutor whose efforts to track down fugitive Nazi war criminals was often obstructed by superiors and underlings.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The People vs. Fritz Bauer

results.headline: Review: In ‘Making a Killing,’ Guns Do Slay People, Children Included
results.summary_short: This documentary focuses on the role of the National Rifle Association in blocking legislation to tighten gun laws.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Making a Killing

results.display_title: Kampai! For the Love of Sake
results.headline: Review: ‘Kampai! For the Love of Sake’ Celebrates Japan’s Best-Known Libation
results.summary_short: Mirai Konishi’s light documentary focuses on brewery experts and others who have devoted their lives to this complex rice-based beverage.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kampai! For the Love of Sake

results.headline: Review: ‘Kingsglaive: Final Fantasy XV,’ Where the Bad Guys Sport Silly Hats
results.summary_short: Unless you’re a fan of the hugely successful Final Fantasy video game series, this big-screen version is too ludicrous for words.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kingsglaive: Final Fantasy XV

results.headline: Review: In ‘Spaceman,’ a Pitcher Specializing in Brashness
results.summary_short: Josh Duhamel portrays the ballplayer Bill Lee at a stage when he is slowly realizing that his major-league days are over.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Spaceman

results.display_title: A Tale of Love and Darkness
results.headline: Review: From Natalie Portman, Israel’s Birth Distilled in Mood and Memory
results.summary_short: “A Tale of Love and Darkness,” based on Amos Oz’s memoir, depicts a family caught up in the conflict and confusion leading to Israel’s war of independence.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Tale of Love and Darkness

results.headline: Review: ‘When Two Worlds Collide’ Portrays a Battle for the Amazon
results.summary_short: This dutiful documentary casts indigenous protesters against the government and commercial interests intent on exploiting Peru’s rich natural resources.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of When Two Worlds Collide
